text: And in that notation, of course, the theorem can be written as with this set of symbols here, equally well.
So let's just give a couple of examples.
The first example is the one that we did last time very laboriously.
If you take the function F of x, which happens to be x cubed over 3, then if you differentiate it, you get, well, the factor of 3 cancels.
So you get x squared.
That's the derivative.
And so by the fundamental theorem, so this implies by the fundamental theorem that the integral from, say, a to b of x squared dx, that's the derivative here.
This is the function we're going to use as f of x here.
Is equal to this function here, f of b minus f of a.
That's here, this function here.
So that's f of b minus f of a.
And that's equal to b cubed over 3 minus a cubed over 3.
Now, in this new notation, we usually don't have all these letters.
All we write is the following.
We write the integral from a to b.
And I'm going to do the case of 0 to b, because that was the one that we actually did last time.
So I'm going to set a equals 0 here.
And then the problem we were faced last time was this.
And as I said, we did it very laboriously.
But now you can see that we can do it in 10 seconds, let's say.
